title: R41214
content: The Department of Defense and Full-Year Continuing Appropriations Act, 2011 (P.L. 112-10) provides $4.54 billion for legislative branch activities for FY2011, continuing funding from the previous year with a 0.2% across-the-board rescission. The legislative branch operated on various continuing resolutions until the enactment of this legislation on April 11, 2011. The Department of Defense and Full-Year Continuing Appropriations Act, 2011 (P.L. 112-10) provided funding for legislative branch activities for FY2011, with reductions in funding for specific programs. Multiple proposals were considered before the enactment of this legislation, including reductions in funding for the House of Representatives and the Library of Congress. The House passed H.R. 1 with amendments related to the House, leading to the final funding decisions outlined in P.L. 112-10. The House and Senate passed amendments affecting spending levels in the 112th Congress. H.Res. 22 reduced authorized amounts for various offices and committees, while S.Amdt. 182 proposed budget reductions for the Senate. The Senate adopted an amendment on March 16, 2011, to reduce its budget by at least 5%. The FY2011 legislative branch budget request was $5.12 billion, a 10% increase from FY2010. Previous budgets were $4.656 billion for FY2010 and $4.4 billion for FY2009. Additional funding was provided for the Government Accountability Office in FY2009. The FY2011 legislative branch budget request was $5.12 billion, with the largest increase proposed for the Capitol Police. The Senate bill (S. 3799) contained $3.136 billion, with reductions in funding for programs like the Open World Leadership Program. The Senate bill (S. 3799) for FY2011 legislative branch appropriations contained $3.136 billion, $435.6 million less than requested. The President requested $15.956 million for Capitol Police in FY2010 supplemental appropriations. Both House and Senate versions of H.R. 4899 included funding for widows and heirs of deceased Members of Congress. The Senate version also had $12.96 million for the Capitol Police for a new radio system. The FY2010 Supplemental Appropriations Act (P.L. 111-212) funded these items. Title I of the annual appropriations bill includes various branch agencies such as the Senate, House of Representatives, Capitol Police, Congressional Budget Office, and others. Title II typically contains general administrative provisions, like prohibiting funds for private vehicle maintenance and addressing staff compensation. The annual appropriations bill includes provisions for various branch agencies and general administrative rules, such as funding for awards and settlements, landscape maintenance, and restrictions on guided tours of the Capitol. Additional titles may be included for specific provisions, like continuity of representation in the House of Representatives in extraordinary circumstances. The legislative branch appropriations bill in FY1978 had a different structure with Title I for Congressional Operations and Title II for Related Agencies. Additional titles were occasionally included for purposes like capital improvements. Since the 110th Congress, both House and Senate Appropriations Committees established Legislative Branch Subcommittees. The House subcommittee was absent in the 109th Congress, and the Senate continued its practice of having a Legislative Branch Subcommittee. The FY2011 U.S. Budget requested $5.10 billion for legislative branch activities, a 9.6% increase from FY2010. The increase was mainly for mandatory expenses like salary adjustments and personnel costs. The Capitol Police requested an additional $15.956 million for a new radio system. Hearings for the Legislative Branch Subcommittees in 2010 were held on specific dates. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved $914.15 million for FY2011, with an increase in internal operations budget to $1.04 billion. The Senate requested an increase of $115.76 million for internal operations in FY2011, representing a 12.5% increase over FY2010. Funding levels for Senate committees were presented, with a $164.57 million request for inquiries and investigations, and $15.84 million for the Committee on Appropriations account. Funding was provided at FY2010 levels for both accounts. The Office Expense Account for Senators provides funds for office administration, including allowances for administrative, clerical, and legislative assistance, as well as office expenses. A total of $458.62 million was requested for FY2011, an increase of $36.62 million from the previous year. P.L. 112-10 reduced the account by $12.0 million. The House requested $1.42 billion in new budget authority for its internal operations, an increase of 3.6% over the previous year. Funding for House committees saw a 12.3% increase in the FY2011 request compared to FY2010 levels. The House requested $1.42 billion in new budget authority for its internal operations, an increase of 3.6% over the previous year. Funding for House committees in FY2011 saw a 12.3% increase compared to FY2010 levels. The second subheading contains funds for the personnel and nonpersonnel expenses of the Committee on Appropriations, with a requested amount of $32.30 million, an increase of 3.2% over FY2010. The Members' Representational Allowance (MRA) requested $671.07 million for FY2011, representing a 1.7% increase over FY2010. The Green the Capitol Initiative was created in March 2007 by Speaker Nancy Pelosi and others. The late Representative Juanita Millender-McDonald requested an environmentally responsible working environment for House employees. $3.9 million was allocated in FY2008 for green initiatives, including new light bulbs and an E-85 gasoline pump. An amendment allowed the Chief Administrative Officer to use the House Services Revolving Fund for these initiatives. The CAO was allowed to use the House Services Revolving Fund for environmental activities like energy and water conservation. Funding for the Green the Capitol Initiative varied each year, with $1 million allocated in FY2009, $2.5 million in FY2010, and $500,000 in FY2011. The U.S. Capitol Police received $340.14 million in funding under P.L. 112-10 for security of the Capitol Complex. The US Capitol Police received $340.14 million in funding for FY2011, lower than their requested $376.02 million. The funding is divided into salaries and general expenses accounts for various purposes like employee benefits, equipment, and security measures. The US Capitol Police received $340.14 million in funding for FY2011, lower than their requested $376.02 million. This funding covers dignitary protection, intelligence analysis, hazardous material response, training programs, and other administrative and technical support. Additionally, $26.98 million was allocated for Capitol Police buildings and grounds within the Architect of the Capitol account. In FY2009, the U.S. Capitol Police budget saw a 27.2% increase over the previous year. Hearings in Senate and House subcommittees discussed budget shortfall issues, including salary miscalculations and difficulties in predicting overtime costs. The possibility of transferring budget responsibility to another legislative branch agency was also raised. The Architect of the Capitol oversees maintenance and operation of the Capitol Complex. The Architect of the Capitol is responsible for various buildings and grounds, including the Library of Congress, Capitol Power Plant, Botanic Garden, Capitol Visitor Center, and Capitol Police buildings. The Architect's operations are funded through 10 accounts, with a budget of $585.77 million provided in P.L. 112-10, which includes a $14.6 million rescission for the Capitol Visitor Center. This is a decrease from the requested budget of $754.81 million, representing a 25.5% increase over the previous year. In FY2009, a 55.4% increase ($642.7 million) was requested and a 28% increase ($529.6 million) was provided. The Capitol Power Plant utility tunnels' condition and necessary repair funds have been discussed during recent appropriations hearings due to health and safety violations. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) identified potential hazards in the Capitol utility tunnels, including excessive heat, asbestos, falling concrete, lack of egress, and communication issues. A settlement agreement was reached in May 2007 to address workers' concerns. The Architect of the Capitol and the Office of Compliance have been discussing steps to improve conditions in multiple hearings since 2006. Other committees have also expressed concerns about the tunnels and related allegations. The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions, Subcommittee on Employment and Workplace Safety, addressed tunnel safety concerns during a March 1, 2007 hearing on asbestos effects. Congress allocated funds for Capitol Power Plant repairs in FY2006 and FY2007, but did not support the Architect of the Capitol's request for funds in FY2008. The FY2009 Omnibus provides $56.4 million for the utility tunnel project, with the Architect originally requesting $126.65 million. AOC indicated that work would begin in early 2009 and extend through 2011. The FY2010 budget request contained $45.77 million for the tunnel program. During a House hearing in April 2009, it was mentioned that the project is ahead of schedule and under budget. The House-passed bill contained $16.85 million, with a total of $134,000,000 appropriated for abating hazards. AOC reassessed its plans for repairs and decreased the fiscal year 2010 budget request. The AOC has revised its plans for the utility tunnel project, reducing the estimated cost to $16.85 million for fiscal year 2010. The total project cost is now $176.13 million. The Committee commends these efforts and expects the AOC to address safety hazards in the tunnels by June 2012. The FY2011 budget request includes $13.95 million. AOC's requested administrative provisions were not included in P.L. 112-10. The Architect of the Capitol (AOC) was granted authority to fix salaries for senior positions and use streamlined procurement procedures under the Federal Acquisition Streamlining Act. This authority was granted through the passage of bill H.R. 6399 in December 2010. The bill also made AOC appropriations available for property acquisitions and allowed for fixing salaries of up to 32 positions at the Senior Executive Service rate. Administrative language regarding acquisitions was also addressed in FY2010. During FY2010, the House and Senate Legislative Branch Subcommittees discussed the Architect's project prioritization, deferred maintenance, and employment authorities for senior staff. Topics at the hearings included renovations to the Cannon House Office Building, energy audits, CVC-related items, potential budget impacts, repairs in the Capitol Power Plant utility tunnels, and staffing levels. The subcommittee discussed the preliminary findings of a blue ribbon panel examining a proposed fire enclosure of the Russell Senate Office Building staircases. Steven Ayers, Acting Architect of the Capitol since February 4, 2007, was nominated to a 10-year term by President Barack Obama on February 24, 2010. The nomination was referred to the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration, which held a hearing on April 15, 2010. The nomination followed the passage of H.R. 2843, the Architect of the Capitol Appointment Act of 2010, in the House on February 3, 2010. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) requested a $2.12 million increase in funding for FY2011, with a focus on increasing full-time staff to 258 from 254. The House subcommittee discussed this request and related issues during a hearing on March 17, 2010. The Ford House Office Building is where Dr. Douglas Elmendorf, Director of the Congressional Budget Office, addressed questions on diversity, hiring, healthcare coordination, and budget score requests. The Library of Congress supports Congress with research services, including acquisitions, preservation, legal research, copyright laws, policy analysis, and services for the blind and physically handicapped. The Library of Congress requested $674.79 million for FY2011, an increase of 4.9% over the previous year. The budget for FY2011 includes $431.76 million for salaries and expenses and $17.76 million for the Copyright Office. The Library of Congress requested $674.79 million for FY2011, including funds for the Copyright Office, Congressional Research Service, Books for the Blind and Physically Handicapped, and Library buildings and grounds. The budget allocations varied from the requested amounts, with some receiving increases and others receiving decreases. The Library of Congress requested a $55.41 million increase for FY2011 for fire and life safety projects and a new storage module in Fort Meade, MD. This would support multi-year projects and administrative provisions, including authority for fund activities and transfer authority among Library of Congress headings. This would support multi-year projects and administrative provisions. Additionally, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) works for Congress by responding to requests for studies of federal government programs and expenditures. GAO may also initiate its own work and was allocated $546.22 million under P.L. 112-10, which was lower than the requested $601.12 million. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) received $531.0 million in FY2009 and an additional $25 million in P.L. 111-5 for responsibilities under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. The House subcommittee discussed GAO's staffing level, diversity, technology assessments, and studies on Iraq and Afghanistan. P.L. 112-10 provided $135.07 million, lower than the $166.56 million requested by the Government Printing Office (GPO). The Government Printing Office (GPO) requested $166.56 million for FY2010 but received $135.07 million under P.L. 112-10. This amount was lower than the $147.46 million provided in FY2010 and represented a 13.0% increase from the previous year. GPO's budget authority is divided into three accounts, with varying levels of funding for each. The Government Printing Office (GPO) requested $44.21 million for FY2010, an 8.1% increase from the previous year. P.L. 112-10 provided $1.66 million for the revolving fund and $25.70 million for the congressional printing and binding account. The request included funding for information technology development, facilities repairs, continuity of operations projects, and workforce retraining programs. The Office of Superintendent of Documents oversees the printing, binding, and distribution of government publications for specified recipients at no charge. This includes a variety of publications such as the Congressional Record, U.S. Code, committee reports, and other documents. The office also funds the mailing of government documents for Members of Congress and federal agencies, compiles catalogs and indexes of government publications, and distributes them to designated libraries. The Office of Compliance administers and enforces the Congressional Accountability Act, applying employment and workplace safety laws to Congress and certain legislative branch entities. The budget for FY2011 was initially requested at $4.858 million, with a revised figure of $4,675,491, representing a 6.82% increase from the previous year. The FY2011 budget for the Office of Compliance was increased by 7.5% from the previous year. Issues discussed in House and Senate subcommittee hearings included fire and life safety, staff salaries, office space, and hazards reduction. The Open World Leadership Center supports democratic changes in other countries by inviting their leaders to observe democracy in the US. The Open World Leadership Center was established in 2000 to support the relationship between Russia and the United States. It invites young leaders from various countries to observe democracy and free enterprise in the US. The program was expanded in 2003 to include more countries, and in 2004, eligibility was extended to other designated countries. The center is housed in the Library of Congress and receives funding from P.L. 112-10 for $11.38 million. The Open World Leadership Center, located at the Library of Congress, has requested $14.0 million for FY2010, a $2.0 million increase from the previous year. Funding for the program has fluctuated in recent years, with a decrease in budget authority noted. There is a push for the program to become financially independent through private funding efforts. The Open World Center seeks to raise private funding to reduce reliance on Legislative Branch appropriations. Efforts are being made to attract different participants by potentially associating with the executive branch. The Center's Board of Trustees is working with the State Department and judiciary to establish a shared funding mechanism. The FY2008 Consolidated Appropriations Act required Open World to prepare a report on options for transferring the Open World Leadership Center to an executive branch department or agency. The Stennis Center received $430,000 in FY2011, and there have been discussions about refunding the Office of Technology Assessment for scientific studies. Some Members support refunding the Office of Technology Assessment (OTA) through "Dear Colleague" letters and legislation. Others suggest that technology assessments could be done more cost-effectively by existing legislative branch agencies. The FY2008 Consolidated Appropriations Act allocated $2.5 million to GAO for technology assessments, with funding continuing in FY2009. Representative Rush Holt requested $35 million for OTA in FY2010. Discussions included the possibility of other agencies like CRS and GAO conducting these studies, comparing costs and timeliness with reestablishing OTA. During the FY2010 House report, funding was provided for GAO to conduct technology assessment studies at the fiscal year 2009 level. Representative Rush Holt and Dr. Francesca Grifo advocated for the restoration of funding for OTA during a subcommittee hearing. Discussions included updating authorizing statutes for OTA and ensuring research resources are accessible to all Members of Congress. The subcommittee discussed cost-effective assessments in existing agencies and FY2011 and FY2010 legislative branch appropriations. Relevant sites include House and Senate Committees on Appropriations, CRS Appropriations Products Guide, Congressional Budget Office, Government Accountability Office, and Office of Management & Budget.
